required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Self-Administered Lidocaine Gel for Pain Management With IUD Insertion
clinical_study.official_title: Self-Administered Lidocaine Gel for Pain Management With IUD Insertion: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: For intrauterine device (IUD) insertion, currently there are no standardized clinical guidelines for pain management. The investigators aim to explore whether adequate pain relief is possible through self-administered, non-invasive means alone. Reducing pain associated with IUD insertion may benefit patients and providers. When patients are comfortable during their procedure, it is likely the provider can more quickly and with fewer complications perform the insertion. The investigators propose to explore the effect of a locally applied vaginal lidocaine gel in place of the standard of care pain management, no intervention, prior to IUD insertions. This is a superiority, blinded, randomized controlled trial.

primary_outcome.measure: (IUD Insertion): Pain perceived by Visual Analogue Scale (0-100 mm) immediately following procedure completion
primary_outcome.time_frame: 20-30 after lidocaine or surgical lubricant inserted
primary_outcome.description: Pain immediately after speculum removal as measured by a Visual Analog Scale (VAS)

secondary_outcome.measure: Anticipated pain as measured by a Visual Analog Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Pain anticipated measured by a Visual Analog Scale (VAS)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately prior to procedure; upon arrival to procedure room
secondary_outcome.description: Pain prior to procedure as measured by a Visual Analog Scale (VAS)

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain after speculum placement as measured by a Visual Analog Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Pain immediately after speculum placement as measured by a Visual Analog Scale (VAS)

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain after tenaculum placement as measured by a Visual Analog Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Pain immediately after tenaculum placement as measured by a Visual Analog Scale (VAS)

arm_group.description: If the subject is assigned to the experimental group (vaginal lidocaine jelly): She will be given a pre-filled vaginal inserter with 10 ml of 2% lidocaine jelly) and will be asked to insert it vaginally 20-30 minutes prior to the start of her procedure. The subject will not know if she received the active drug or a placebo.

If the subject is assigned to the control group (sterile, surgical lubricant jelly): â€¢She will be given a pre-filled vaginal inserter with 10 ml of surgical lubricant jelly and will be asked to insert it vaginally 20-30 minutes prior to the start of her procedure. The subject will not know if she received the active drug or a placebo.

intervention.description: Patient-administered vaginal Lidocaine jelly verse surgical lubricant jelly
Patient-administered vaginal surgical lubricant jelly verse Lidocaine jelly

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Elective IUD insertion (any type of IUD, copper or hormonal); at an out-patient setting at Stanford; English or Spanish speaking, and ability to give informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
Any pre-operative use of misoprostol; or use of PO pain control medication (i.e. ibuprofen or acetaminophen) prior to procedure. Allergy to study medications: lidocaine, or surgical lubricant jelly, known uterine anomaly; prior cervical surgery; and no prior use of tampons.
